results.title: Primary sources: the raw material of history
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Introduction to History”.
The film uses London as a place to show how different primary sources can be used to study its history. The primary sources include an excavated Roman bath-house, early documents, pottery, maps, paintings, business records and archival film.

results.title: About Trevelyan
results.creator_credit: Peter Scroggs, Open University and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Introduction to History”.
A discussion between four academic historians about the ways in which the discipline of history, as they study and teach it, makes demands which sharply differentiates it from other kinds of history. They relate these points in the first place to the virtues and defects of some of the work of G. M. Trevelyan. Then B. Dodson of York University, discusses a newspaper series called “The Making of the British” and shows five points at which it departs from what he would consider professional standards of history.

results.title: Introducing Chemistry
results.media_note: Sorry, we don't have images or video for this item.

results.title: Formulas and equations
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Introducing Chemistry”.
This is the first of three films for a beginning unit in chemistry. It explains and demonstrates the basic language of chemistry, the symbols used in formulas and equations. Acids, bases and salts are defined in terms of their formulas. Basic terms encountered include compound, gas, precipitate and radical as well as the concepts of structural formulas and “balanced” equations.

results.title: How atoms combine [B&W]
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Introducing Chemistry”.
Three basic types of atomic bonding are clearly and simply illustrated: covalent bonding in which there is an equal sharing of electrons by two or more atoms; polar covalent bonding in which one atom has a greater share than the others; and ionic bonding in which one atom seems to take nearly full control of the electrons from the other atom or radical.

results.title: Types of chemical change
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Introducing Chemistry”
Introduces four basic types of chemical reactions: direct combination, decomposition, simple displacement and double displacement.
